newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore June non-oil exports rise 8.8 percent.
newsitem.headline: Singapore June non-oil exports rise 8.8 percent.

text.p: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports rose a higher-than-expected nominal 8.8 percent in June year-on-year, the Trade Development Board (TDB) said on Monday.
They fell 1.0 percent in May and a Reuters poll of 12 economists last week had forecast a 6.3 percent rise for June, when the TDB said Singapore exported goods worth Singapore $7.45 billion.
The TDB said global electronics demand -- which fuels some 70 percent of Singapore's non-oil domestic exports -- had begun a turnaround likely to continue in the coming months.
"However, competition in the industry is likely to intensify. This will exert downward pressure on prices of key electronic products, resulting in a squeeze in profit margin," it said in a statement.
That was evident in the 29 percent decline in prices of 16-megabit dynamic random access memory chips since March 1997, the statement said.
Similarly, major personal computer makers have been slashing prices to maintain market share in highly competitive markets, it said.
"On balance, TDB's assessment is that the earlier projected total trade growth of five to seven percent for 1997 would be achieved," it added.
In real terms, non-oil exports rose 11.2 percent in June to S$9.69 billion after rising 0.6 percent in May.
Singapore's non-oil domestic exports expanded by 4.4 pct in the second quarter after contracting by 4.1 percent in the first quarter, the TDB said.
For the first half of 1997, the growth was 0.2 percent.
Total trade rose by 5.3 percent in the second quarter of 1997, reversing the 2.5 percent contraction in the first quarter.
For the first half of 1997, total trade growth was 1.4 percent.
